intro: Gastrosiphon, commonly known as the bladderwort, is a genus of aquatic plants belonging to the family Lentibulariaceae. These plants are characterized by their small, bladder-like structures called vesicles, which are used to trap tiny aquatic organisms. Gastrosiphon species are typically found in freshwater environments such as ponds, ditches, and slow-moving streams. They are carnivorous plants that supplement their nutrient intake by digesting captured prey. Their unique morphology and ecological role make them an interesting subject in the study of aquatic botany.
